intro: Bocagea coriacea, commonly known as the roughleaf bocagea, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its woody stems and small, oval-shaped leaves that are covered in a rough, leathery texture. The plant produces clusters of white, bell-shaped flowers that bloom in the spring. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in woodland edges and moist thickets. Bocagea coriacea is a member of the Onagraceae family, which includes other flowering plants such as willows and evening primroses.
